snippet: Japanese-Americans who answered “no” to two critical questions in a loyalty test were confined to Tule Lake during World War II. Now, their families are seeking answers.
abstract: Families and friends of the Japanese-Americans who were confined to the Tule Lake, Calif, interment camp during World War II make a pilgrimage there every other year; those confined at the maximum-security camp were stigmatized after the war for having answered 'no' to key questions on a government-administered loyalty test.
lead_paragraph: Japanese-Americans who answered “no” to two critical questions in a loyalty test were confined to Tule Lake during World War II. Now, their families are seeking answers.

headline.seo: Japanese-American Pilgrimage to Internment Camp — Tulelake Journal
headline.main: At Internment Camp, Exploring Choices of the Past
headline.print_headline: At Internment Camp, Pilgrims Explore Choices of the Past
